title: Multivariable MR Tutorial
text: Multivariable Mendelian Randomisation (MVMR) form instrumental variable analysis estimates direct effect multiple exposures outcome using genetic variants instruments. MVMR R package facilitates estimation causal effects using MVMR, well including range sensitivity analyses evaluating underlying assumptions approach. methods included MVMR originate Sanderson, Spiller, Bowden (2021), available .

title: Multivariable MR Tutorial
text: Fitting interpreting MVMR models can achieved following 5 steps given : Obtain data Format data Assess instrument strength Assess horizontal pleiotropy Estimate causal effects steps shown figure , highlighting R function used step. workflow MVMR analysis.

title: Multivariable MR Tutorial
text: following information necessary estimate causal effects using MVMR: Gene-exposure associations variant selected instrument exposure. Corresponding standard errors gene-exposure associations. Gene-outcome associations instrument. Corresponding standard errors gene-outcome associations. data frame rawdat_mvmr, included MVMR package shows example data obtained MRBase. data extracted MRBase using TwoSampleMR R package, mrmvinput_to_mvmr_format() function can used convert data MVMR data format. specifically requires gene-exposure associations included SNPs, gene-outcome associations, corresponding standard errors. case, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C), high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C), triglycerides (Trg) selected exposures, systolic blood pressure (SBP) outcome interest. suffix _beta used denote association estimates, _se denotes standard errors. Please note MVMR can take arbirtary number exposures (greater 1), three exposures selected purely illustration. first 6 rows rawdat_mvmr : Note final column SNP contains rsid numbers genetic variant. necessary conducting MVMR, assist follow-analyses. Summary data LDL-C, HDL-C, Triglycerides originate GLGC, SBP data obtained using UK Biobank.

what: Estimating pairwise covariances between SNP associations
title: Multivariable MR Tutorial
text: MVMR approach requires pairwise covariances instrument pairs exposures known across SNPs testing sensitivity analyses. However, often reported published GWAS analyses. continuing MVMR therefore necessary select one following three solutions: Estimate covariance terms using individual level data individual level data available GWAS summary estimates obtained, snpcov_mvmr() function can used calculate necessary covariance terms. Estimate covariance terms using phenotypic correlation exposures. estimate correlation (phenotypic) exposures available, phenocov_mvmr() function can used provide approximation necessary covariance terms. function takes phenotypic correlation exposures standard error SNP-exposure betas inputs. Obtain gene-exposure associations non-overlapping samples. gene-exposure associations estimated seperate non-overlapping samples, covariances zero design. therefore necessary calculate set covariances, although approach can difficult apply due lack suitable sources data. necessary data provided snpcov_mvmr() phenocov_mvmr() functions, set covariance matrices produced equal number SNPs used estimation. saving output object, possible use information downstream senstivity analyses assumption testing. phenocov_mvmr() function requires gene-exposure standard errors, can useful estimate covariance matrices initially formatiing data. illustrative example provided step 6, creating object Xcovmat using phenocov_mvmr() function.

title: Multivariable MR Tutorial
text: Downstream functions MVMR package rely upon prior formatting raw summary data using format_mvmr() function. Specifically, format_mvmr() checks organises summary data columns use MVMR analyses. format_mvmr() function takes following arguments: BXGs: subset containing beta-coefficient values genetic associations exposure. Columns indicate exposure number, rows representing estimates given genetic variant. BYG: numeric vector beta-coefficient values genetic associations outcome. seBXGs: subset containing standard errors corresponding subset beta-coefficients BXGs. seBYG: numeric vector standard errors corresponding beta-coefficients BYG. RSID: vector names genetic variants included analysis. variant IDs provided (RSID = "NULL"), vector ID numbers generated. Using previous data rawdat.mvmr, can format data using following command: code provided numbered columns argument. example, BXGs = rawdat.mvmr[, c(1, 2, 3)] indicates columns 1, 2, 3 association estimates exposures 1, 2, 3. important note standard error columns seBXGs input order BXGs ensure correct matching association estimates corresponding standard errors. subsequent steps, exposure numbered X1, X2, X3 first, second, third entries BXGs = rawdat.mvmr[, c(1, 2, 3)] argument.

title: Multivariable MR Tutorial
text: univariate two-sample summary MR, genetic variants selected instruments required strongly associated corresponding exposure. quantified regressing exposure upon instrument, evaluating conditional dependence using F-statistic instrument. Conventionally, F-statistic greater 10 used threshold sufficient instrument strength, representing 10% relative bias towards null two-sample MR setting. Multivariable MR relies upon extension assumption, requiring instruments strongly associated corresponding exposure conditioning remaining included exposures. Conditional instrument strength quantified conditional F-statistic distribution univariate F-statistic. Consequently, conventional instrument strength threshold 10 can used. details available . strength_mvmr() function used evaluate instrument strength MVMR setting. function contains two arguments: r_input: formatted data frame created using format_mvmr() function object class MRMVInput mr_mvinput() function MendelianRandomization package. gencov: variance-covariance matrix effect genetic variants exposure. obtained either snpcov_mvmr(), phenocov_mvmr(), set zero omitted. Note: strength_mvmr() function output warning variance-covariance matrix provided. Please see Step 1 information. Continuing previous example, can evaluate conditional strength instruments exposure using following command case set instruments sufficiently strong MVMR estimation using conventional F-statistic threshold 10. However, note manually set gencov zero, likely appropriate given SNP-exposure estimate obtained sample. Using random phenotypic correlation matrix, conditional F-statistics can calculated
code: sres <- strength_mvmr(r_input = F.data, gencov = 0) #> Warning in strength_mvmr(r_input = F.data, gencov = 0): Covariance between #> effect of genetic variants on each exposure not specified. Fixing covariance at #> 0. #>  #> Conditional F-statistics for instrument strength #>  #>             exposure1 exposure2 exposure3 #> F-statistic  46.33671  67.80463  38.80184 mvmrcormatrix <- matrix(c(1, -0.1, -0.05, -0.1, 1, 0.2, -0.05, 0.2, 1), nrow = 3, ncol = 3) Xcovmat <- phenocov_mvmr(mvmrcormatrix, F.data[, 7:9]) sres2 <- strength_mvmr(r_input = F.data, gencov = Xcovmat) #>  #> Conditional F-statistics for instrument strength #>  #>             exposure1 exposure2 exposure3 #> F-statistic  48.20993  69.55193  39.77326

what: Step 4: Test for horizontal pleiotropy using conventional Q-statistic estimation
title: Multivariable MR Tutorial
text: Horizontal pleiotropy can evaluated using modified form Cochran’s Q statistic respect differences MVMR estimates across set instruments. case, observed heterogeneity indicative violation exclusion restriction assumption MR (validity), can result biased effect estimates. Importantly, weak instruments can increase false positive rate pleiotropy detection, heterogeneity effect estimates due weak instrument bias conflated heterogeneity result pleiotropic bias. correction possible estimate heterogeneity pleiotropy Q-statistic minimisation. function pleiotropy_mvmr() can used test heterogeneity, requiring arguments strength_mvmr(); r_input gencov. example covariance matrices Step 3:
code: pres <- pleiotropy_mvmr(r_input = F.data, gencov = 0) #> Warning in pleiotropy_mvmr(r_input = F.data, gencov = 0): Covariance between #> effect of genetic variants on each exposure not specified. Fixing covariance at #> 0. #> Q-Statistic for instrument validity: #> 683.0807 on 141 DF , p-value: 4.880403e-72 pres <- pleiotropy_mvmr(r_input = F.data, gencov = Xcovmat) #> Q-Statistic for instrument validity: #> 682.843 on 141 DF , p-value: 5.36533e-72

title: Multivariable MR Tutorial
text: Two MVMR estimation methods provided MVMR package. first method fits inverse variance weighted (IVW) MVMR model, providing estimates direct effect exposure upon outcome. performed using ivw_mvmr() function shown : case, effect estimates interpreted direct effects LDL-C (exposure 1), HDL-C (exposure 2), Trg (exposure 3) SBP. Estimates robust weak instruments pleiotropic bias, therefore rely upon underlying MVMR assumptions satisfied.
code: res <- ivw_mvmr(r_input = F.data) #> Warning in ivw_mvmr(r_input = F.data): Covariance between effect of genetic #> variants on each exposure not specified. Fixing covariance at 0. #>  #> Multivariable MR #>  #>               Estimate Std. Error   t value  Pr(>|t|) #> exposure1 -0.021845061 0.01417255 -1.541364 0.1254538 #> exposure2  0.003735249 0.01033779  0.361320 0.7183973 #> exposure3  0.025572042 0.01601913  1.596344 0.1126351 #>  #> Residual standard error: 2.197 on 142 degrees of freedom

title: Multivariable MR Tutorial
text: MVMR assumptions potentially violated, specifically instruments weak exhibit pleiotropy, possible obtain robust estimates Q-statistic minimisation. can performed using qhet_mvmr() function. important highlight phenotypic covariance matrix used input, set estimated covariance matrices previously formed gencov argument. also noted number exposure instruments increases, estimation using qhet_mvmr() may prove difficult, owing substantial amount computing power required. can initially relaxed computing 95% confidence intervals .
code: res1 <- qhet_mvmr(F.data, mvmrcormatrix, CI = FALSE, iterations = 100) #> Warning in qhet_mvmr(F.data, mvmrcormatrix, CI = FALSE, iterations = 100): #> qhet_mvmr() is currently undergoing development. res1 #>            Effect Estimates #> Exposure 1    -0.0264865644 #> Exposure 2     0.0094372624 #> Exposure 3     0.0002575009

title: Authors and Citation
text: Wes Spiller. Author, maintainer. Jack Bowden. Author. Eleanor Sanderson. Author. Tom Palmer. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Sanderson E, Spiller W, Bowden J (2021). “Testing correcting weak pleiotropic instruments two-sample multivariable Mendelian randomization.” Statistics Medicine, 40(25), 5434–5452. doi:10.1002/sim.9133.
code: @Article{mvmr,   author = {E. Sanderson and W. Spiller and J. Bowden},   title = {{Testing and correcting for weak and pleiotropic instruments in two-sample multivariable Mendelian randomization}},   year = {2021},   doi = {10.1002/sim.9133},   journal = {Statistics in Medicine},   volume = {40},   number = {25},   pages = {5434--5452}, }

title: MVMR
text: MVMR can installed MRCIEU R-Universe install MVMR directly GitHub repository, first make sure remotes package installed: MVMR package can installed using: update package just run command .
code: install.packages("MVMR", repos = c("https://mrcieu.r-universe.dev", "https://cloud.r-project.org")) install.packages("remotes") library(remotes) install_github("WSpiller/MVMR", build_opts = c("--no-resave-data", "--no-manual"), build_vignettes = TRUE)

title: MVMR
text: written MVMR R package perform multivariable Mendelian randomization analyses, including heterogeneity statistics assessing instrument strength validity. package accommodates number exposures greater 1, currently includes range functions estimating causal effects, well assessing conditional instrument strength pleiotropic bias. detailed description regarding function, please install package input vignette("MVMR")

title: MVMR
text: corresponding paper published Statistics Medicine, can accessed : Testing correcting weak pleiotropic instruments two-sample multivariable Mendelian randomization. Statistics Medicine, 2021. [Internet]. 2021;sim.9133.

title: MVMR
text: project licensed GNU GPL v3.

BYG numeric vector beta-coefficient values genetic associations outcome. seBXGs matrix containing standard errors corresponding matrix beta-coefficients BXGs. seBYG numeric vector standard errors corresponding beta-coefficients BYG. RSID vector names genetic variants included analysis. variant IDs provided vector ID numbers generated.

code: r_input <- format_mvmr(   BXGs = rawdat_mvmr[, c("LDL_beta", "HDL_beta")],   BYG = rawdat_mvmr$SBP_beta,   seBXGs = rawdat_mvmr[, c("LDL_se", "HDL_se")],   seBYG = rawdat_mvmr$SBP_se,   RSID = rawdat_mvmr$SNP ) names(r_input) #> [1] "SNP"      "betaYG"   "sebetaYG" "betaX1"   "betaX2"   "sebetaX1" "sebetaX2" class(r_input) #> [1] "data.frame"  "mvmr_format"

what: Convert an object of class MRMVInput from the MendelianRandomization package to the MVMR mvmr_format class — mrmvinput_to_mvmr_format
title: Convert an object of class MRMVInput from the MendelianRandomization package to the MVMR mvmr_format class — mrmvinput_to_mvmr_format
text: Creates data.frame additional class mvmr_format object class MRMVInput generated MendelianRandomization::mr_mvinput().

title: Convert an object of class MRMVInput from the MendelianRandomization package to the MVMR mvmr_format class — mrmvinput_to_mvmr_format
Convert an object of class MRMVInput from the MendelianRandomization package to the MVMR mvmr_format class — mrmvinput_to_mvmr_format
text: dat Object MendelianRandomization::mr_mvinput().

title: Convert an object of class MRMVInput from the MendelianRandomization package to the MVMR mvmr_format class — mrmvinput_to_mvmr_format
text: Object class mvmr_format, MVMR format

title: Convert an object of class MRMVInput from the MendelianRandomization package to the MVMR mvmr_format class — mrmvinput_to_mvmr_format
code: if (require("MendelianRandomization", quietly = TRUE)) {   bx <- as.matrix(rawdat_mvmr[, c("LDL_beta", "HDL_beta")])   bxse <- as.matrix(rawdat_mvmr[, c("LDL_se", "HDL_se")])   dat <- MendelianRandomization::mr_mvinput(     bx = bx,     bxse = bxse,     by = rawdat_mvmr$SBP_beta,     byse = rawdat_mvmr$SBP_se,     snps = rawdat_mvmr$SNP   )   dat <- mrmvinput_to_mvmr_format(dat)   head(dat)   class(dat) } #> [1] "data.frame"  "mvmr_format"

title: mvmr (legacy) — mvmr
text: Note: function old version MVMR package replaced future: gencov argument set zero using mvmr().

title: mvmr (legacy) — mvmr
text: r_input formatted data frame using format_mvmr() function object class MRMVInput MendelianRandomization::mr_mvinput() gencov Calculating heterogeneity statistics requires covariance effect genetic variants exposure known. can either estimated individual level data, assumed zero, fixed zero using non-overlapping samples exposure GWAS. value 0 used default. weights value specifying inverse variance weights used calculate IVW estimate Cochran's Q statistic. Currently first order weights available (1).

title: mvmr (legacy) — mvmr
text: object class "MVMRIVW" containing following components: summary summary MVMR regression model, including estimated coefficients, standard errors, t-statistics, p-values, heterogeneity statistics. coef estimated coefficients, standard errors, t-statistics, corresponding (two-sided) p-values. Q_strength data frame displaying modified Cochran's Q statistics assessing instrument strength respect exposure. Q-statistic increases proportionally instrument strength, analogous univariate MR analyses, value equal greater 10 can used minimum threshold instrument strength. Note statistics informative evaluate p-values. Q_valid modified form Cochran's Q statistic measuring heterogeneity causal effect estimates obtained using genetic variant. Observed heterogeneity indicative violation exclusion restriction assumption MR (validity), can result biased effect estimates. p_valid p-value corresponding heterogeneity measure instrument validity (Q_valid)

title: mvmr (legacy) — mvmr
text: Fits IVW multivariable Mendelian randomization model using first order weights. function returns object class "MVMRIVW", containing regression estimates, estimated heterogeneity measure instrument strength (Q_strength), estimated heterogeneity measure instrument validity (Q_valid).

title: mvmr (legacy) — mvmr
text: Sanderson, E., et al., examination multivariable Mendelian randomization single-sample two-sample summary data settings. International Journal Epidemiology, 2019, 48, 3, 713–727. doi:10.1093/ije/dyy262

title: mvmr (legacy) — mvmr
text: Wes Spiller; Eleanor Sanderson; Jack Bowden.

title: mvmr (legacy) — mvmr
code: # Example using format_mvmr formatted data r_input <- format_mvmr(   BXGs = rawdat_mvmr[, c("LDL_beta", "HDL_beta")],   BYG = rawdat_mvmr$SBP_beta,   seBXGs = rawdat_mvmr[, c("LDL_se", "HDL_se")],   seBYG = rawdat_mvmr$SBP_se,   RSID = rawdat_mvmr$SNP ) mvmr(r_input, 0, 1) #>  #> Multivariable MR #>  #>               Estimate Std. Error    t value  Pr(>|t|) #> exposure1 -0.031003996 0.01302925 -2.3795686 0.0186526 #> exposure2  0.006039167 0.01029181  0.5867933 0.5582678 #>  #> Residual standard error: 2.209 on 143 degrees of freedom #>  #> F-statistic: 3.27 on 2 and 143 DF, p-value: 0.0408 #>  #> ------------------------------ #> Q-Statistics for instrument strength: #>  #>   exposure1 exposure2 #> Q  9739.922  10401.49 #>  #> ------------------------------ #> Q-Statistic for instrument validity: #>  #> 695.5924 on 142 DF , p-value: 7.338e-74  # Example using MRMVInput formatted data from the MendelianRandomization package if (require("MendelianRandomization", quietly = TRUE)) {   bx <- as.matrix(rawdat_mvmr[, c("LDL_beta", "HDL_beta")])   bxse <- as.matrix(rawdat_mvmr[, c("LDL_se", "HDL_se")])   dat <- MendelianRandomization::mr_mvinput(     bx = bx,     bxse = bxse,     by = rawdat_mvmr$SBP_beta,     byse = rawdat_mvmr$SBP_se,     snps = rawdat_mvmr$SNP   )   mvmr(r_input = r_input, gencov = 0, weights = 1) } #>  #> Multivariable MR #>  #>               Estimate Std. Error    t value  Pr(>|t|) #> exposure1 -0.031003996 0.01302925 -2.3795686 0.0186526 #> exposure2  0.006039167 0.01029181  0.5867933 0.5582678 #>  #> Residual standard error: 2.209 on 143 degrees of freedom #>  #> F-statistic: 3.27 on 2 and 143 DF, p-value: 0.0408 #>  #> ------------------------------ #> Q-Statistics for instrument strength: #>  #>   exposure1 exposure2 #> Q  9739.922  10401.49 #>  #> ------------------------------ #> Q-Statistic for instrument validity: #>  #> 695.5924 on 142 DF , p-value: 7.338e-74

title: pleiotropy_mvmr — pleiotropy_mvmr
text: Calculates modified form Cochran's Q statistic measuring heterogeneity causal effect estimates obtained using genetic variant. Observed heterogeneity indicative violation exclusion restriction assumption MR (validity), can result biased effect estimates. function takes formatted dataframe input, obtained using function format_mvmr(). Additionally, covariance matrices estimated effects individual genetic variants exposure can also provided. can estimated using external data applying snpcov_mvmr() phenocov_mvmr() functions, input manually. function returns dataframe including conditional Q-statistic instrument validity, corresponding P-value.

title: qhet_mvmr — qhet_mvmr
text: Fits multivariable Mendelian randomization model adjusting weak instruments. functions requires formatted dataframe using format_mvmr() function, well phenotypic correlation matrix pcor. obtained individual level phenotypic data, constructed correlation matrix correlations previously reported. Confidence intervals calculated using non-parametric bootstrap. default, standard errors produced can calculated setting se = TRUE. number bootstrap iterations specified using iterations argument. Note calculating confidence intervals present can take substantial amount time.

title: qhet_mvmr — qhet_mvmr
text: r_input formatted data frame using format_mvmr() function object class MRMVInput MendelianRandomization::mr_mvinput() pcor phenotypic correlation matrix including correlation exposure included MVMR analysis. CI Indicates whether 95 percent confidence intervals calculated using non-parametric bootstrap. iterations Specifies number bootstrap iterations calculating 95 percent confidence intervals.
